When they were talking about cavitation causing damage, people might be asking how bubbles can damage components. Those cavitation bubbles are created by extremely powerful, highly focused, localized vacuums. When those bubbles return to the liquid and loose the vacuum, they collapse with so much energy, it’s like tiny bombs exploding. They reach extremely high temperatures reportedly in the tens of thousands degrees, enough to melt any metal. So the bubbles eat away the components, severely damaging them. The principle of cavitation is how ultrasonic cleaners work.

Copy from another comment by me on a Starlink launch:

"
Ok Elon, going great on the Starlinks, but...
Not doing so well on the improving rocket motors eh ?
Yes a few percent here and a few percent there. But none on your staff have a 'x10' capability.
Well, this one is for you, but you may only patent it under general usage, not private.
Here's how it works:
The engine's thrust is limited by the pressure of the output exhaust, right ?
Did you know you can increase the pressure while it's outside the engine, but still in the Bell nozzle ?
Introducing Z-Ex-engine-afterburner, which does the following: While still in the Bell nozzle, introduction
of a fast heat producing substance, such as thermite. Now the exhaust will grow hotter on the inside
of the flame, but not incontact with the Bell nozzle itself, and thus heating the nozzle little more. Where the
heat is introduced, the gas exhaust will increase pressure, but outside of the engine.
Future spaceships will rely on this principle much more, since it's very lightweight,
while adding lot's of thrust.
Have fun cooking this one up for real and ur team too. Remember going to space is an adventure, not a job.

Note: The Z-Ex-engine-afterburner is free of use to anyone who wants to patent it for general use,
barring private use patenting or no-use patents.
Note2: It's pronounced "the Zee-Ex-engine-afterburner" not ZEX
Note3: 'x10' capability is pronounced "times ten" capability.
Note4: It'll work when positioned right, and when the substance is lightweight but much heat producing.
Too early and it'll fry the engine, too late, and the thrust increase won't make much difference.

Alternately, you can rev the engine to like 90%, and with that the niitial heat (and fuel usage), and then introduce
the Z-Ex component for equal thrust. At may be possible to use regular water as a fuel exhaust this way,
reducing the expensive LOX, while still maintaining similar thrust. The water should then be
introduced in boiling temp, or possibly vapor, while cooling the engine components that are at max temp,
while then in evaporated state, have a cooler exhaust to begin with at same pressure, and then the Z-ex component added.

It's ok if the team hates me for not coming up with this, but it's neccessary to get more cargo
up into space more easily.
"

On Mars, the engine shrouds will also need to stop dust/dirt/pebble blowback during touchdown.  So the equipment in the engine area needs to be very robust against rock projectiles, otherwise a solid or Whipple shield specifically for that danger.  However a basic shielding against micrometeorites would also be needed during travel between planets.  So a shield designed for those outside  dangers and optimized for reuse and weight would be needed even if the engine can take unlimited heat from launch.  This is similar to the shielding of petrol car engines for driving on dirt roads and pebble driveways, and those designs tend to control robustness against expected projectile paths rather than an actual shield, which might not be workable for high speed micrometeorites in interplanetary space or LEO.

just figured I'd comment that the "area under the force-time curve vs mass flow" he's talking about is actually just Isp / specific impulse..

The integral of (or area under) the force-time curve is defines the total impulse for the given time bounds, which when divided by the propellant mass flow results in the time integrated specific impulse (Isp = Thrust/Prop_mass_flow_rate => integral of force / Prop_mass_flow_rate = integral of Isp).

I think what he means is the difference between the time-averaged/spec-rated Isp vs time-variable/instantaneous Isp (and especially different than the analytical/predicted Isp). He is completely correct in that force varies over time and so does instantaneous Isp. But in the end, all you actually care about is the total or average Isp - which you get by integrating the instantaneous performance over time - hence area under the thrust-time curve (though because the mass-flow varies with time as well, you actually are interested in the integration of Isp, not just thrust).

And of course, when he references the assumptions and all, he's likely referring to analytical/predicted vs experimental Isp. Isp is predicted based on engine design and analytical methods, whereas the experimental is based on the actual measured thrust and mass flow. Obviously, you're always going to have discrepancies and you're really more interested in the experimental result.

About the cavitation erosion issue at around 28:00, cavitation bubbles erode metal when they collapse, not necessarily when they “hit” the blade. The integral of force with respect to time is impulse. The metric that Elon was proposing would be dividing the impulse (kg*m/s) by the mass flow (kg), leaving us with change in velocity, or dV.

edit: I know that this is different than the change in velocity of the actual craft, but I guess my point is that he was talking like he was talking about something other than specific impulse while describing another analogous measurement that leads us back to specific impulse. I think Elon's point might have been that engines cannot be considered to have a single, unchanging Isp, but if that were the case, then we all already knew that considering the whole sea-level/vaccum optimization of engines.

The standard word for "area under the force-time curve" is "impulse". "Specific" is the word for "divided by mass", so "specific impulse" is the term for "area under the force-time curve divided by total mass of propellant used". It would have units of speed except that people multiply by g to measure it in units of time.

Elon is asking for something else, area under the force-time curve divided by mass flow rate. But this, as stated, doesn't seem to make a lot of sense as an engine measuring metric since it depends on how long you run the engine for, which doesn't just depend on the engine but on the entire vehicle. If he instead means force divided by mass flow rate, that would be an instantaneous measure of specific impulse.

Tim Dodd asked for a more sexy name for the “area under the force versus time curve” after Elon told Tim that it is the most important thing.  Tim - There already is a sexy name for this and Its called “Impulse” (units = Newton Seconds).  Impulse = J = (Force) multiplied by (final time - beginning time).  “Specific Impulse” (units = seconds) = Isp = (Impulse, J) divided by the sea-level weight of the fuel that you will burn over the time period you used to compute the Impulse.  As Elon pointed out, the pure math term for “the area under the force versus time curve” is: The integral (means “area under”) of the curve plotted on a Cartesian coordinate system that represents Force (plotted on the Y axis) from time t1 to time t2” on the X axis.

Area under the Force Time curve. Actually, integral of F(t)dt. This is the net work performed by the engines. What you have in the end to lift payloads. Why not just call it AFTC? Engine Force Time Area, EFTA? Force Time Area, FTA? (I like FTA) And Musk is of course correct, for a certain reaction mass flow, only the FTA, thrust/weight of engines and weight of tanks, are interesting. All the rest, ISP, thrust, chamber pressure, energy values, efficiency rates, are just details under the hood, that should not make you lose focus on the only things that matter in the end.

Area under the force time curve - he is just saying to use calculus to calculate it. ISP is a snapshot at one particular fraction of a second. He's suggesting to take the efficiency of the entire fuel load. It's like a car, horsepower is acceleration (not torque, people/marketing really misuse torque). However your car isn't pulling away very fast in 6th gear. That's because you might have 500hp, but you only have it for one very specific RPM. In first gear you're closer to the correct RPM, the horsepower is higher, car accelerates faster.

Its the same deal with ISP, maybe you've got 360ISP but if you've only got that at one specific point you're not getting the whole picture. Much better to get 350ISP for the whole launch than 320ISP for most and 360ISP for a very short time. You'd do that by getting a graph of the force on the y axis and time on the x, then calculate the area under the curve. Ie to use integration.

I also don't dislike the name integrated force. Specific impulse is good because it describes exactly what it is. Integrated force doesn't entirely, but its pretty close. If you know you're talking about rockets you're probably going to have a good idea exactly what it's about.

@27:45 they're talking about cavitation wear. it is not the bubble that produces the stress/fatigue but the collapse of the bubble that generates the extreme localized pressure.

a bubble is a void, a region of low density... when that low pressure region collapses, the surrounding medium rushes in to fill the (empty) space. this implosion can generate extreme pressure (even shaped as a jet) over a small surface area in the vicinity or on the surface of a metal part and with enough repetition fatigue/wear becomes an issue. all metals get "tired" if subjected to repetitive stress.

FYI: the area under a Thrust vs. Time curve already has a name. It's "Total Impulse". Any model rocketeer will be familiar with the term, because the solid rocket motors they use are rated by Itot. A-class motors provide up to 2.5 Newton-seconds, B motor, up to 5 Ns. Each letter doubles the maximum total impulse. Hobby / sport motors go up to O class, with a maximum Itot of 40,960 Ns.

It's crazy how much pollution one  rocket engine causes  Here's a little article that I found... There's more if you go to research it  .. Approximately two-thirds of propellant exhaust is released into the stratosphere (12 km-50 km) and mesosphere (50 km-85 km), where it can persist for at least 2-3 years. This is significant due to the climate impact of rocket emissions that are trapped in those layers.The alumina (Al2O3), chlorine (converted from hydrochloric acid, HCl), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydroxyl (OH), and water vapour (H2O) in rocket launch plumes all contribute to ozone depletion through chemical reactions in the Earth’s stratosphere. This naturally poses a risk to humanity, as ozone protects the Earth from harmful UV radiation.     Just a little tidbit that they don't seem to like to talk about ..

By placing a measure of emphasis on "we managed to get rid of torch igniters (in the main chambers)" Elon's specificity is not the same thing as stating that they had been dispensed with altogether.

But it is also my understanding that if the Oxygen and Methane gases used to provide reaction mass in Raptor engines are combined at specific ratios, combustion can be spontaneous.

That characteristic could probably be applied to instigation of combustion elsewhere in a full flow combustion cycle engine where the volume of space in which deflagration is initiated and sustained is substantially less, such as the hot stage for the turbo pumps which provide propellant components to the main chamber for example.

Exhaust venting to the main chamber from that stage in the propellant reticulation system of a full flow combustion cycle engine could then ignite propellant provided by the pumps it energizes to the main chambers which in turn could dispense with torch igniters.

It is undoubtedly not the only or necessarily the best solution but is a credible possibility.

Impulse.  It's just called Impulse.  I find it interesting that Elon didn't know that.  It's 1st year college (or AP) level Physics.  But there's a reason that Impulse itself is not a good measure of the engine's performance: it doesn't relate the efficiency of the engine.  For example, I could build a humongous engine that eats up a boatload of fuel and look at it's Impulse--by finding the area under the Force vs. time curve.  It might have a super high amount of thrust that lasts for a long time which would give a big Impulse value.  But that doesn't mean it's at all efficient.  For an analogy, you could compare the Impulse of an 18-wheeler tractor with a regular car.  The truck's impulse would be huge, but that doesn't really tell you about the performance of the engine.

It would be great if SpaceX could use simple electrically driven pumps instead of relying on gas turbines - unfortunately, battery energy density isn't quite sufficient to make that work. But a hybrid alternative may be practical - use small electric pumps to provide just enough high pressure fuel and oxidizer to feed the oxygen rich and fuel rich turbines that then power the main fuel and oxidizer pumps. The advantages is that, with no "crossfeeding", it makes startup, throttling and shutdown much easier, control is greatly improved, and it makes it much easier to balance fuel rich and oxidizer rich turbines

It's not the "bubbles" that eat the metal because they are litteraly nothing (vacuum). It's the hydraulic ram effect of them collapsing up against the metal. It's like a small water jet. FYI: the area under a Thrust vs. Time curve already has a name. It's "Total Impulse". Any model rocketeer will be familiar with the term, because the solid rocket motors they use are rated by Itot. A-class motors provide up to 2.5 Newton-seconds, B motor, up to 5 Ns. Each letter doubles the maximum total impulse. Hobby / sport motors go up to O class, with a maximum Itot of 40,960 Ns.
